Award.AwardTitle: RI:Collaborative Research: Robust Ornithopter Flight - from Engineering Models to Cooperative Indoor Maneuvers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Flapping flight provides high maneuverability for indoor environments.
To achieve robust intelligence for tasks such as search and indoor
navigation, the maneuverability of an ornithopter will be combined
with a learning approach which makes minimal assumptions about the
nature of disturbances and obstacles. We propose to develop
algorithms for ornithopters to cooperate in sensing and navigation in
typical indoor environments without prior maps. Our research will be
verified with full three dimensional dynamic simulation, a
multi-tethered laboratory test-bed, as well as with actual indoor
flying ornithopters.

The key research issues to be addressed in this work are:
1) improved ornithopter mechanics and aerodynamics
2) robust ornithopter flight control strategies
3) learning algorithms for cooperative navigation
of ornithopters using only simple sensor information

This research will advance understanding of high maneuverability
flapping wing vehicles for indoor flight. By combining research from
the levels of mechanics to learned behavior in a real indoor
environment, we will test how performance at each level can be
integrated to achieve robust intelligence.

Our project will provide interdisciplinary education for students in
achieving robust intelligence through the combination of mechanics,
sensing, control, and learning. This research can lead to flying
robots which can robustly enter unknown and hazardous indoor
environments, potentially keeping rescue workers out of harms way.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research activities have focused on novel design, modeling, fabrication, and testing of flapping-wing MAVs. Our findings can be summarized under three main headings: (i) Design of Flapping-wing MAVs where the flapping is actively controlled by a motor while the rotation is tuned passively by exploiting the aerodynamics. This work was studied extensively in  the PhD dissertation of Zaeem Khan that was completed in June 2009. Two  journal papers have appeared in the AIAA Journal in 2011 based on these works.
(ii) Design of a flapping mechanism using the theory of spherical mechanisms. This work is based on M.S. thesis of M. McDonald and was
published in the ASME Journal of Mechanisms and Robotics. (iii) Study the role of flexibility of wings in MAV Applications based on the M.S. thesis of A. Agrawal. This work was published in a special issue on Biomimetic Design in 'Advanced Robotics'.

Our project personnel have benefited from interdisciplinary work on novel designs of flapping-wing MAVs which integrate aerodynamics, mechanism synthesis, and hardware fabrication. Our educational activities have included demonstrations to middle school and high school students. Our group has given a number of presentations to teachers in the local high schools. A list of journal publications arising form this work is

Agrawal, A.; Agrawal, S. K., "Design of Bio-Inspired Flexible Wings for Flapping-Wing MAV Applications", Advanced Robotics, p. 979, vol.
23, (2009),
McDonald, M.; Agrawal, S. K., "Design of a spherical four-bar mechanism for flapping-wing micro air vehicle applications", ASME J. of
Mechanisms and Robotics, p. , vol. 2, (2009),

Khan, Z. A. and Agrawal, S. K., “Study of Biological inspired Flapping Mechanism for Micro Air Vehicles”, AIAA Journal, Vol. 49, No. 7, 2011, 1354-1365.

Khan, Z. A. and Agrawal, S. K., “Optimal Hovering Kinematics of Flapping Wings for Micro Air Vehicles”, AIAA Journal, Vol. 49, No. 2, 2011, 257-268.
